lessons.title: What are Number Systems?
lessons.description: Learn the fundamentals of number systems and why different bases exist.

sections.title: Introduction to Number Systems
sections.content:
A number system is a way of representing numbers. The most common system we use daily is the decimal system (base 10), but computers use binary (base 2), and programmers often use hexadecimal (base 16) and octal (base 8).

Each number system has a base, which determines how many unique digits are available.

sections.title: Understanding Bases
sections.problem: In base 10, we have digits 0-9. How many digits does base 2 have?

questions.question: What is the base of the decimal number system?
questions.explanation: Decimal system is base 10, using digits 0-9

lessons.title: Understanding Binary
lessons.description: Learn about binary numbers and how computers use them.

sections.title: What is Binary?
sections.content:
Binary is the base-2 number system, using only two digits: 0 and 1. Each position in a binary number represents a power of 2.

For example: 1010 in binary = 1×2³ + 0×2² + 1×2¹ + 0×2⁰ = 8 + 0 + 2 + 0 = 10 in decimal

exercises.hint: Multiply each bit by its position value (powers of 2)

lessons.title: Fractional Conversions
lessons.description: Learn how to convert fractional numbers between different bases.

sections.title: Understanding Fractional Parts
sections.content:
Just like whole numbers, fractional parts can be represented in any base. The digits after the decimal point represent negative powers of the base.

For example: 0.101 in binary = 1×2⁻¹ + 0×2⁻² + 1×2⁻³ = 0.5 + 0 + 0.125 = 0.625 in decimal
